## What is machine learning?

["The science of getting computers to learn without being explicitly programmed"]{style="font-size: 0.8em; font-style: italic;"}

:::::: {style="font-size: 0.7em; line-height: 1.3; display: flex; gap: 2em;"}
::: {.fragment style="flex: 1;" data-fragment-index="1"}
<strong>Supervised learning</strong><br> • Maps input to output: X → Y labels<br> • Classification, regression, neural networks<br>

<em>Examples:</em><br> – X-ray image → tumor/no tumor<br> – Words → next word (LLM)
:::

::: {.fragment style="flex: 1;" data-fragment-index="2"}
<strong>Unsupervised learning</strong><br> • No labels<br> • Clustering, anomaly detection, data reduction<br>

<em>Examples:</em><br> – Customer segmentation<br> – Fraud detection
:::

::: {.fragment style="flex: 1;" data-fragment-index="3"}
<strong>Reinforcement learning</strong><br> • Rewards and punishments guide learning<br>

<em>Examples:</em><br> – Self-driving cars<br> – Robotics
:::
::::::

## Statistics vs. machine learning

## Inference vs. prediction {.smaller}

<ul class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1">

<li>

Inference involves drawing conclusions about a population based on a sample of data; it is concerned with understanding relationships, estimating parameters, and testing hypotheses

<ul>

<li>Focuses on why something happens</li>

<li>E.g., identifying which factors significantly impact disease risk</li>

</ul>

</li>

</ul>

<ul class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2">

<li>

Prediction refers to using a model to forecast future outcomes based on current or historical data

<ul>

<li>Focuses on what will happen</li>

<li>E.g., predicting whether a patient will develop a disease given a set of health metrics</li>

</ul>

</li>

</ul>

<ul class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3">

<li>Traditional statistical models are typically designed for inference and focus on interpretability but can do both inference and prediction</li>

</ul>

<ul class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4">

<li>Machine learning models optimize prediction and offer limited inference</li>

</ul>

## Statistical models vs. machine learning models

<ul class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1">

<li>Statistical models are probabilistic and explicitly consider uncertainty</li>

</ul>

<ul class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2">

<li>Statistical models start with preconceived structure and typically assume additivity of predictor effects when specifying the model</li>

</ul>

<ul class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3">

<li>Machine learning models are more empirical and allow for higher-order interactions that are not pre-specified; do not attempt to isolate the effect of any single variable</li>

</ul>

::: {style="font-size: 0.4em; line-height: 1.1; margin-top: 0.5em; color: #555;"}
Harrell, Frank. (2018, April 30). Road map for choosing between statistical modeling and machine learning. <em>Statistical Thinking</em>. <a href="https://www.fharrell.com/post/stat-ml/" target="_blank">https://www.fharrell.com/post/stat-ml/</a>.
:::

::: notes
-   SMs employ assumptions based on an underlying probabilistic theory
-   SMs can have a tremendous amount of complexity
-   ML models model the complex patterns and higher-order interactions in data in a “black box” fashion
:::

## When to use SM vs. ML {.smaller}

<ul class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1">

<li>ML may work best when overall prediction is the goal without being able to describe the impact of any one predictor</li>

</ul>

<ul class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2">

<li>ML requires large sample sizes (typically 200 events per candidate predictor)</li>

</ul>

<ul class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3">

<li>ML might work better for high signal-to-noise situations (e.g., visual and sound recognition)</li>

</ul>

<ul class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4">

<li>ML tends to work well when learning a simple concept</li>

</ul>

<ul class="fragment" data-fragment-index="5">

<li>

ML tends to work poorly when:

<ul>

<li>Learning complex concepts from small amounts of data</li>

<li>Performs on new types of data (data the model was not trained on)</li>

</ul>

</li>

</ul>

::: {style="font-size: 0.4em; line-height: 1.1; margin-top: 0.5em; color: #555;"}
Harrell, Frank. (2018, April 30). Road map for choosing between statistical modeling and machine learning. <em>Statistical Thinking</em>. <a href="https://www.fharrell.com/post/stat-ml/" target="_blank">https://www.fharrell.com/post/stat-ml/</a>.
:::

## Additional AI/ML considerations

## AI/ML roles {.smaller}

-   Data scientist
-   ML engineer (also new: AI engineer)
-   Data engineer
    -   Organize and manage data, data access, security in a cost-effective way
    -   Needed for project with large data (≥ TB)
-   AI product manager
-   Training resources:
    -   Emphasis on concepts and algorithms not just specific AI implementations

::: notes
Can get started with MB, GB of data
:::

## One second rule {.smaller}

|  |  |
|----------------------|--------------------------------------------------|
| **What is it?** | <em>If a human can complete a task in about one second of thought, AI may be able to automate it</em> |

<br>

```{=html}
<style>
```

|  |  |
|----------------------|--------------------------------------------------|
| **Why it works** | • Pattern recognition: AI learns from data like human intuition<br>• Low complexity: quick decisions are ideal for AI<br>• Automation potential: repetitive, structured tasks fit well |
| **Examples** | • Object recognition in images<br>• Text prediction<br>• Document classification |
| **When the rule breaks down** | • Deep reasoning required<br>• Ambiguity and subjectivity |
:::

## Considerations for LLMs

<ul class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1">

<li>

Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG)

<ul>

<li>Combines an existing LLM with a custom knowledge base to provide up-to-date domain specific answers</li>

</ul>

</li>

</ul>

<ul class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2">

<li>

Fine-tuning pre-trained models

<ul>

<li>Requires less data and compute power than training from scratch</li>

<li>Uses existing models that are fine-tuned on domain-specific data</li>

</ul>

</li>

</ul>
